p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Milton Dick ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the third report of the Petitions Committee for the 47th Parliament.
The report read as follows—
Chair Ms Susan Templeman MP
Deputy Chair Mr Ross Vasta MP
Mr Sam Birrell MP
Ms Alison Byrnes MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Mr Garth Hamilton MP
Ms Tracy Roberts MP
Ms Meryl Swanson MP

span.span: The committee met in private session in the 47th Parliament on 26 October 2022, 9 November 2022 and 23 November 2022.
1. The committee resolved to present the following 50 petitions in accordance with standing order 2

p.span: From 10 petitioners—requesting a ban on all anime (Japanese animation) from being digitally transmitted (EN4484)
From 29 petitioners—requesting no GP fees (EN4485)
From 22 petitioners—requesting the inclusion of child care worker occupation into the skilled occupation list (EN4490)
From 500 petitioners—requesting action on the genocidal war in Tigray (EN4491)
From 14 petitioners—requesting an Australian republic (EN4493)
From 2 petitioners—requesting the legal age for owning a mobile phone be 18 years (EN4495)
From 592 petitioners—requesting redress for survivors of child sex abuse in gymnastics (EN4498)
From 32 petitioners—requesting the strengthening of data protection laws for consumers (EN4501)
From 6 petitioners—requesting free treatment for all children under 18 (EN4502)
From 28 petitioners—requesting support for the people of Iran (EN4503)
From 118 petitioners—requesting proven false allegations be penalised. (EN4506)
From 49 petitioners—requesting an increase in the validity period for professional year, Naati and English score. (EN4508)
From 40 petitioners—requesting the shut down of Iran's embassy and banishing of all associated personnel (EN4511)
From 21 petitioners—requesting the Iranian Ambassador be summoned over the protest crackdown (EN4512)
From 4 petitioners—requesting the new class of Australian submarines be named Rainbow Warriors (EN4515)
From 18 petitioners—requesting a block on international scam calls (EN4518)
From 1368 petitioners—requesting reintroduction of covid isolation mandates (EN4520)
From 13 petitioners—requesting a subsidised 12 month Diploma of Education (EN4521)
From 25 petitioners—requesting Australia stop business with Iran and enter into human rights negotiations (EN4524)
From 133 petitioners—requesting action on government sponsored violence against civilians in Iran (EN4525)
From 18 petitioners—requesting a stop to ISIS brides coming back to Australia (EN4526)
From 5 petitioners—requesting the revision of pornographic media production and distribution laws (EN4527)
From 41 petitioners—requesting a reduction in visa processing time (EN4529)
From 16 petitioners—requesting a Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme for pets (EN4531)
From 89 petitioners—requesting support for the Iran protest against the Islamic Republic (EN4533)
From 32 petitioners—requesting the Iranian Ambassador be summoned and expelled (EN4535)
From 62 petitioners—requesting a reduction in the duration of 491 visas (EN4536)
From 5 petitioners—requesting an investigation into how to encourage more voters to vote (EN4539)
From 39 petitioners—requesting the Iranian government are held accountable for the death of Mahsa Amini (EN4540)
From 17 petitioners—requesting a picture of the Canberra War Memorial to replace the Queen on the $5 note (EN4543)
From 69 petitioners—requesting a visa ban on people linked to Iranian regime (EN4544)
From 25 petitioners—requesting a requirement for consumer electronics to use USB-C for charging (EN4545)
From 8599 petitioners—requesting the designation of the IRGC as a terrorist organization in Australia (EN4547)
From 6304 petitioners—requesting whole-of-life reductions to veteran retirement pay (EN4548)
From 12 petitioners—requesting an investigation into the Nunyara Aboriginal Health Service (EN4549)
From 37 petitioners—requesting a reduction in the price of diesel (EN4551)
From 4 petitioners—requesting Parliamentary reform (EN4552)
From 8076 petitioners—requesting mRNA-vaccines are taken off the market (EN4554)
From 27 petitioners—requesting a review of the tax free threshold (EN4555)
From 20 petitioners—requesting more LGBTQIA+ related questions in the census (EN4557)
From 54864 petitioners—requesting the expulsion of the Islamic Republic of Iran ambassador (EN4559)
From 13 petitioners—requesting compulsory seat belts in buses (EN4560)
From 223 petitioners—requesting a declaration of the current Russian regime as "terrorist" (EN4562)
From 7 petitioners—requesting an aged pension after working for 20 years (EN4564)
From 26 petitioners—requesting an investigation into the issues forcing doctors to move to mixed billing (EN4566)
From 3759 petitioners—requesting the expulsion of Iran's diplomats and sanctioning of officials (EN4567)
From 810 petitioners—requesting the creation of a national stuttering awareness week in Australia. (EN4568)
From 279 petitioners—requesting that 491 visa holders be given the same rights as permanency residency (EN4569)
From 3880 petitioners—requesting urgent action towards the Islamic Republic of Iran (EN4571)
From 10579 petitioners—requesting the renunciation of the Islamic Republic of Iran (IRI) for human rights violations (EN4572)

From the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs to a petition requesting recognition of the paediatric physiotherapy skill shortage (EN4011)

From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition regarding human rights abuse in illegally occupied Kashmir by Indian government (EN4023)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition requesting the rejection of control of all global organisations (EN4037)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition requesting condemnation of aggression against Ukraine. (EN4041)
From the Minister for Social Services to a petition requesting an increase in paid parental leave from 18 to 26 weeks (EN4056)
From the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs to a petition requesting the removal of balance of family test for parent permanent visas (EN4064)
From the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs to a petition regarding the validity period of skills assessment for trade occupations (EN4086)
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care to a petition requesting the reinstatement of abdominoplasty to Medicare (EN4087)
PETITIONS
Presentation
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 50 petitions:

subdebateinfo.title: Arts and Culture: Cartoons and Animation

p.span: Arts and Culture: Cartoons and Animation
We have a generation of young Australians who have developed an unhealthy addiction to Anime and other Japanese animated media.

This has led to these people becoming unproductive and disassociate from their reality which will have dire consequences in the long term, such as the development of socially and sexually maladaptive behaviour, and the neglect of personal health resulting in conditions such as obesity.

We therefore ask the House to completely ban the digital distribution and transmission of anime (2d Japanese media) and other digitally-produced media which portray an unrealistic reality to our youth.
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN4484)
Medicare

General Practitioners (GP) are charging fees above and beyond the Medicare rebate for consultation. People of Australia are now out of pocket. We wish for a review of Medicare rebates for GP consultation.
We therefore ask the House to stop general practitioners (GP) charging fees for consultations above what they receive via Medicare.
from 29 citizens (Petition No. EN4485)
Migration

As we all aware of child care educator crisis all over in Australia; I am hereby suggesting a solution to include "child care worker (group leader only)" occupation back in skilled occupation list of Australia so that overseas childcare worker or those who are struggling to find the employer in a complex process can apply their visa by themselves without relocating from one place to another. Although their is DAMA 482 and 494 visas are in place, but these are very complex visa and one cannot find the good outcome out of it. Child care worker(group leader only) are in high demand and child care centers are struggling to find the candidates because the occupation in not on SOL.

We therefore ask the House to look into the matter and take a necessary step or action to think about the situation and include the child care worker (group leader only) occupation into skilled occupation list.
from 22 citizens (Petition No. EN4490)
Tigray
A humanitarian catastrophe has unfolded in Tigray due to the siege enforced by the Ethiopian, Eritrean Governments and Amhara Militia.

Since November 2020, the genocidal war on Tigray has seen over 500,000 deaths. Over 100,000 women and girls as young as six have been victims of sexual violence. More than 70,000 Tigrayans were forced to flee their homes to neighbouring Sudan, remaining in vulnerable conditions as reported by reputable international media and documented by UN organisations.

The Ethiopian and Eritrean Governments continue to commit war crimes and caused a deliberate man-made famine through weaponised starvation. Drones have been utilised to bombard residential areas daily, resulting in civilian deaths, including children.

The siege on Tigray has exacerbated the suffering of Tigrayans. Tigray's only functioning hospital has shortages of medical equipment, causing the inability of patients to receive medical support and die of preventable conditions.

We therefore ask the House to 1) Consider the intake of Tigrayan refugees and grant humanitarian visas for those in Sudan and neighbouring countries. Refugees deserve the right of protection, and Australia should implement solutions that enforce safety for those at risk of persecution in their home countries. 2) Triple Australia's aid commitment to-date and support humanitarian groups on the ground, such as MSF and ICRC. 3) Discontinue all non-emergency support to the Ethiopian and Eritrean governments. Impose economic-diplomatic sanctions to assist in defunding this genocidal war and request for the immediate withdrawal of Ethiopian and Eritrean forces to end the siege on Tigray.
from 500 citizens (Petition No. EN4491)
Australian Constitution

I believe that Australia should be a Republic, along with many others. A Republic is an opportunity for Independence and the creation of a new foundation of Government, which importantly enables bringing together one of the oldest cultures in the world ; Indigenous Australians with the increasingly multicultural society that is Australia. Unity and Justice, modern take on democracy for our beautiful island home. A chance to assist in healing our people, enable positive change and improve the structure of Government and build much needed and practical infrastructure. Give power back to the Australian people and importantly give the 'landback' to the Aboriginal & Torres Strait Islander people. Let the Australian people make their own decisions for their country. Power to the people. Sovereignty never ceded.

We therefore ask the House to make Australia a REPUBLIC, with inclusion of a multicultural council whom advises the President much like the 'privy council' and/or 'UN'. Australia is a modern multicultural society we need a modern & Independent Government whom knows it's people. We can become a stronger country by doing so. Build needed infrastructure and fulfill the needs of the people for a healthy and more productive population. Ie. Rural areas all over Australia need more hospitals, schools, mental health facilities, rehabilitation services. Etc
from 14 citizens (Petition No. EN4493)
Telecommunications

Kids these days are spending too much time inside, they don't care about nature or education. They only care about scrolling on TikTok and seeing the next best thing. We as mature adults need to recognise this problem and do something about it.
We therefore ask the House to make an age to own a mobile phone capable of housing social medias and online interaction. preferable the age of 18.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN4495)
Gymnastics Australia

History records that child sex offenders have circulated throughout gymnastics for decades, praying on little children. I am the victim of one such offender, secured a conviction and have applied for redress through our National Redress Scheme ("the Scheme"). Many others will follow after me, needing a formalised apology and financial justice. The peak body for our sport, Gymnastics Australia, qualifies financially to sign on, and stated almost two years ago it was "on-boarding" with the Scheme. I applied over a year ago, and still GA have not signed up. The Federal Government has the power to withdraw the millions of dollars in funding it delivers to Gymnastics Australia if it refuses to sign up. Our government set up these trigger provisions because it recognised that organisations do not always keep to their promises. We ask the government to exercise its trigger provisions if GA has not signed up by December 2022.
We therefore ask the House to use its trigger provisions to withdraw funding for Gymnastics Australia if it hasn't signed up to the Scheme by December 2022.
from 592 citizens (Petition No. EN4498)
Cybersecurity

Given the recent data breach of millions of Optus customers, and many other data breaches in previous years of various other large companies the current laws regarding the storage of sensitive private information is woefully lacking as is the punishment of companies who do suffer these breaches. There is little to nothing that a person can do to protect themselves from credit card fraud and identity theft if their personal information such as the information stored by Optus ie passport number, license number, address, date of birth is illegally accessed and sold.

The people effected by the negligence of the companies responsible for the storage and protection of a persons data can and do suffer the long lasting consequences that have significant impact on their finances, time and mental health.

We therefore ask the House to strengthen data protection laws of consumers and private citizens and also instil significant punishments on companies who are in breach of the law, similar to the current data protections of the EU
from 32 citizens (Petition No. EN4501)
Medicare
We request that all minors in Australia be given bulk-billed treatment only for any and all issues. No child should be subject to their parents' wealth for specialist appointments.
We therefore ask the House to require all paediatricians to bulk bill all consultations; and therefore ask that paediatricians are given decent rebates from the consultations.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN4502)
Human Rights: Iran

Since the Islamic Revolution of 1979, Iranian authorities have consistently violated the basic human rights of their citizens. The regime has suppressed all political parties, violated all minority group's rights, and held their own people hostage to pursue their ideological goals in the region, causing severe unrest throughout the Middle East.

After the tragic death of 22-year-old Mahsa Amini, in September 2022, the people of Iran are now again in the streets fighting for their basic rights and demanding the removal of this unjust regime. A young generation of courageous women are leading the way, condemning their compulsory veil and shouting to the world that they will no longer be governed by degrading ideological laws, demanding their freedom.

The Islamic Government is now retaliating with violence, brutally killing their own citizens as they protest, and the People of Iran now urgently are calling for the support of the international community to ensure their calls for change are heard
We therefore ask the House to advise the Australian government to:
1. Condemn the government of the Islamic Republic of Iran for violating the basic human rights of people of Iran, violently suppressing any kind of opposition and killing their own people.
2. Recognise the movement of Iranian people to oppose and protest their government to demand basic human rights and their freedom.
3. To lead by example and request the international community to put pressure on the Islamic regime to stop violating human rights, and massacre of its own people.
from 28 citizens (Petition No. EN4503)
Family Law
Far to many people (particularly men) lose their jobs, children, friends, homes and lives due to the fact that it's incredibly easy to make a false allegation leading to conviction.
These false allegations and their consequences are literally killing our men on a daily basis.
There are no consequences for making such accusations, accusations that are destroying peoples lives.
Children growing up without parents because an accusation has been made, this is horrific.
There is a register for providing false, misleading information if you are a builder, car owner/operator, sex offender and many more.
What about the false allegations that are made against Dads?
Dads that can prove these in court but never get the opportunity?
The family bond must be kept strong but this can be made impossible very easily by just one phone call to the police. An allegation can be made and this is perceived to be truthful.
Basically, you can lie about something that a man has done to you. You will be believed, his life may be destroyed and once the truth comes out, you're okay but that man's life is destroyed.
There must be consequences for this.

We therefore ask the House to consider creating a registry for those proven to have provided false allegations. These allegations must be proven and if found guilty and a fine must be imposed, along with the accusers name added to the register protecting those considering future relationships.
This will help keep the public safe.
from 118 citizens (Petition No. EN4506)
Migration

Petition is because of covid-19 there were no invitation round happen, people who have secured all possible way of getting points to get PR invites but it is almost 3 years there were no sign of invitation for PR and all our efforts for professional year course it got validity for only 36 months which is expired which is worth of 5 points and it is even just a course then comes english exam scores which is really hard to get 8 in ielts/ pte it needs lots of effort and time to practice and to get score but its valid for 3 years and our scores got expired it is worth of 20 points and then the last one is Naati ccl exam which is translation exam which is expensive exam it is only 15-20 minutes exam it is worth of 5 points and because of no invitation round our PY, ENGLISH AND NAATI points got expired which is all sum up 30 points which is a major blow for each and every people who have applied and waited patiently for invitation round for 3 years. Its mainly affected people who got score and completed professional year on 2018, 2019 and even 2020

We therefore ask the House to please accept our request on increasing the validity period for professional year program, English exam score and Naati ccl score and consider our request and please provide us extension for 2 more years.
from 49 citizens (Petition No. EN4508)
Human Rights: Iran

On September 13, 2022, Mahsa (Zhina) Amini, a 22-year-old woman was arrested by the so-called morality police in Tehran for the alleged improper wearing of a mandatory hijab. She was transferred to the moral police headquarters. There are reports by witnesses of hearing screams from inside the police station during the time she was there. According to one of the witnesses, Mahsa had spoken about being severely hit in the head by the police while being transferred. She was transported to Kasra hospital in less than a few hours and was declared brain-dead on arrival. Subsequently, she was announced dead on September 15.

In response to Mahsa's Murder and numerous others like her, Iranian people have taken to the streets for peaceful protests to voice their dissent. The reaction from the regime has been widespread brutality. Several protestors have been shot and killed including young men, women, and children. Numerous protestors have been arrested with no information on their whereabouts, and the government is trying to suppress the protests and the international reflections by shutting down the internet.

We therefore ask the House to shut down the Islamic Republic of Iran's Embassy in Canberra and banish all associated personnel and their families from Australia as members of Iran's terrorist regime. They have no right to live freely in this beautiful country while their fellows are murdering innocent people in Iran.
from 40 citizens (Petition No. EN4511)
Human Rights: Iran

The death of Mahsa Amini at the hands of the Iranian regime's "Morality Police" and the lethal crackdown of protests have so far resulted in the murder of tens of innocent civilians at the hands of the Iranian regime.

This gross violation of basic human rights and the right of citizens to protest peacefully must be condemned by the free world. Leaders of countries such as the United States of America, Canada and Germany have already taken steps by imposing sanctions on Iran and summoning the Iranian ambassadors.

We therefore ask the House to summon or expel the Iranian ambassador over the Islamic regime's lethal crackdown on protests sparked by the murder of a young woman at the hands of the Iranian morality police.
from 21 citizens (Petition No. EN4512)
Defence Procurement

Rainbow Warrior was a Greenpeace boat active in supporting anti-nuclear testing and anti-nuclear waste dumping campaigns during the late 1970s and early 1980s. The Direction Générale de la Sécurité Extérieure (the French intelligence service) bombed Rainbow Warrior in the Port of Auckland, New Zealand on 10 July 1985, sinking the ship and killing photographer Fernando Pereira.

Naming our new submarines after the Rainbow Warrior will demonstrate the keen Australian sense of irony, our support for the environmentally-conscious and LGBTQIA+ communities, and honour the efforts of those who took to the seas for their values despite a wide range of opposition.
We therefore ask the House to name the new class of submarines after the Rainbow Warrior.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN4515)
Cybersecurity
Thousands if not hundreds of thousands of scam calls come into Australia every day. These calls target all Australians but they cost the most vulnerable of Australian citizens thousand of dollars.
Most of these calls appear to come from Voice over IP (VOIP) services which are identifying as legitimate Mobile phone numbers.

We therefore ask the House to investigate ways to identifying these calls as they come into the Australian phone network and potentially identify the ones that are imitating legitimate numbers and block them to protect the Australian public.
from 18 citizens (Petition No. EN4518)
COVID-19: Biosecurity
Effective 15 October, the Covid isolation mandate will be scrapped.
The impact is that Covid positive people (at the peak of their infectivity) are allowed to go out and mingle with the general populace.

With no other forms of preventative measures in place (e.g. no masks, no social distancing), the highly contagious airborne Covid will thus highly likely infect / reinfect a greater number of healthy people.

Whilst Covid may result in mild symptoms for most, there is substantial risk of long Covid and various other health complications as the number of reinfection increases. Additionally, high infection rates drive the further rapid evolution of Covid.
There has not been any compelling evidence-based medical justification provided to substantiate the scrapping of these isolation rules.

There are many families with vulnerable elderlies and family members with various other risk factors, and this change puts these people at higher risk of infection / reinfection; with the flow-on impact of more serious conditions.

The RACGP, AMA and ANMF have all expressed serious concerns regarding the removal of the Covid isolation mandate. These medical and nursing associations have all released statements outlining the medical reasons for maintaining the isolation mandate.
We therefore ask the House to request the Government to reintroduce the Covid isolation mandate.
The Australian Parliament and Government have a duty of care to the vulnerable, elderly, general populace and the proper functioning of the health system.
from 1,368 citizens (Petition No. EN4520)
Education Workforce

There is an identified lack of teachers, combined with short tenure in the industry. Over 50s who have the desire to educate should be encouraged to complete a subsidies 12 month Diploma of Education, in order to qualify them to teach in the school system. They have real life work experience, in addition to life experience. and are more likely to be respected in the classroom.
This would also solve the issue of ageism, with an increasing number of over 50s being overlooked in the employment processes today.

We therefore ask the House to develop a fast-track nationally recognised Diploma of Education for over 50s who wish to teach. This should be open to anybody who has achieved a Certificate 4 or higher at TAFE. The course should then lead into a 12 month job placement with the Department of Education in the relevant sponsoring state.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN4521)
Human Rights: Iran
22-year-old Mahsa Amini was assassinated by the morality police of Iran. This has sparked an uprising in Iran and protests in 150 major cities around the globe.
Peaceful demonstrations of Iran's citizens however, is responded by the iron feast of Iranian's security forces which has left hundreds killed so far.

As I am writing this petition, Iranian's security forces have locked protesting students of Sharif university of technology in the campus and began to brutally massacre them which its horrendous footages are leaking out despite national internet shutdown.

Iran's regime has violated most of, if not all, values we believe and practice in Australia. Although the dictatorship nature of this regime is no news in the past 43 years, what we are observing is an unbelievable level of brutality and inhumanity.

We therefore ask the House to order the government to immediately stop any economic and financial relationship with the government of Iran and begin negotiations on human rights with clear objectives.
from 25 citizens (Petition No. EN4524)
Human Rights: Iran

The Government of Islamic Republic of Iran is using unprecedented violence and is murdering unarmed and peaceful protestors who are demanding justice for Mahsa Amini (RIP) and guarantees of basic human rights for all Iranian citizens.

We therefore ask the House to move a motion for the Foreign Minster to summon the Islamic Republic's ambassador and demand immediate cessation of government sponsored violence against all Iranian citizens especially, women and free all political prisoners.
We further ask the House to move a motion to downgrade political relationship with the Islamic republic to chargés / chargée d'affaires.

We also ask the house to move a motion for appropriate ministries to investigate large investments made by Iranian officials and/or their proxies in Australia and freeze such assets until such time that these assets can be returned to their rightful owners, the democratically elected representatives of Iranians.
from 133 citizens (Petition No. EN4525)
National Security
Stop the isis brides coming to Australia, they have taken part it terrorism and have committed terrorist acts, they represent a danger to Australia should they return.
We therefore ask the House to Ban the isis brides ever returning to Australia
from 18 citizens (Petition No. EN4526)
Arts and Culture: Adult Content

Adult media production and distribution laws are archaic and treat Australian citizens as babies. There are no uniform federal laws, as there are differing and confusing state and territory laws regarding distribution, and production is essentially illegal business-wise. Not only are the laws out of touch with modern Australians, they are out of touch with modern Australian economical needs.

We therefore ask the House to create uniform, federal adult media production and distribution laws that can allow the creation and growth of a healthy, safe, competitive, regulated industry that can rival international industries and clarify the legal rights to the average citizen around producing, purchasing, selling and acquiring adult materials as the current laws are contradictory, confusing and differ from state to territory, leading to confusion and fear over what is, and isn't, currently legally allowed. By revising these laws this will also help the mainstream Australian film and television industry, which is currently flatlining (especially compared to international industries).
from five citizens (Petition No. EN4527)
Migration
We are experiencing a massive backlog regarding the visa applications and processing time. This is causing dismay to immigrants who are trying to make a living here in Australia.
Australia needs skill workers and many are giving up because of this waiting time.

Most immigrants desire the permanent residence to buy a house, have children, set up businesses and the long wait for visas make this reality increasingly distant, which makes these people leave Australia and try other destination countries such as Canada, the UK, and US.
The visas for skilled workers, sponsors and residency are taking more than two years to be processed, which is inconceivable, inhumane and unfair, making people anxious and depressed with this wait.
We therefore ask the House to please improve the process, and do not take more than two years to grant a visa.
It remains my appeal for immigration to speed up with the visas processing time and put an end to the anxiety of those who wait.
from 41 citizens (Petition No. EN4529)
Veterinary Medicines

Currently veterinarians are excluded from the Australian Government's Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which has resulted in a free for all on prescription medications for pets. This has resulted in the establishment of online suppliers providing prescription medications for pets that are 50% or more cheaper than those supplied by many local veterinary clinics. Example 100 Pexion 400mg tablets for idiopathic epilepsy from a local veterinary clinic can cost around $300 in comparison to around $100 from an online supplier. The effectiveness of medications supplied by online suppliers cannot be guaranteed and some may even be toxic to pets. People, pensioners in particular, should not have to choose between buying food/paying bills and buying medications to keep their pets. A Pets Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme would result in less pets being surrendered or even put down due to the exorbitant costs of keeping them alive and healthy.
We therefore ask the House to establish a Pets Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and for veterinarians to be allowed access.
from 16 citizens (Petition No. EN4531)
Human Rights: Iran

After the brutal murder of Mahsa Amini by the so-called "Morality Police" in Tehran, the people of Iran have risen yet again and are peacefully protesting on the streets all around the world demanding only one thing: they don't want the Islamic Republic anymore.

The regime on the other hand is responding with brutal violence, cracking down on unarmed citizens with live ammunition and hoards of thugs in plain clothes and uniforms. Many lives have been lost as a result and so many are arrested, tortured or are in police custody. The regime has also shut down the internet to further isolate Iranian people and to hide its abhorrent, barbaric behavior from the world. These behaviors are acts of terrorism and should be treated as such.

The Islamic Republic is also supporting Russian's war against Ukraine, and has also been involved in terrorist activities in the Middle East and around the world, randomly taking hostages from the foreign visitors to trade them for their frozen money or their terrorist diplomats.
We therefore ask the House to follow the footsteps of Canada and stand with what's right by doing the followings:
1) Summon the Islamic Republic of Iran's envoy in Australia.
2) Terminate Islamic Republic of Iran's membership in the UN women's commission as senator Claire Chandler has already suggested.
3) Add "Sepah Pasdaran" to the list of terrorist groups and sanction their top leaders to ever be able to enter Australia or engage in any activities with this country.
from 89 citizens (Petition No. EN4533)
Human Rights: Iran

Over the last 3 weeks, Iranian government has committed multiple crimes against humanity. This started by murder of Mahsa Amini and was continued by murder of multiple others who came to streets to protests IRI's disregard for freedom of choice, women's rights, use of child soldiers and other basic freedoms. Particularly, the right to freedom of speech which they limited by blocking internet access for 80 million people.
This is on background of numerous oppressions and unaccounted mass killings over the past 43 years.
We, as humans, are concerned for the health and safety of the people whose livelihood is threatened by the irresponsible actions of the IRI.
We therefore ask the House to :
1- summon the Iranian ambassador to demand an explanation for their recent action and request release of all political prisoners.
2- Expel the Iranian ambassador who represents a criminal regime which is not a elected by its people.
3- stop all political relations with IRI that legitimise this criminal and oppressive regime with does not represent it's people
from 32 citizens (Petition No. EN4535)
Migration

We are stuck for three long years for permanent residency. 491 visa holders cannot apply for other visas due to legislation rules. 491 visa holders don't get any benefits until they get permanent residency.
- Not eligible for home loans and car loans.
- Extra foreign stamp duty to buy a house under 491.
- Not eligible for paid parental leave despite working for many years.
- Have to pay international university fees.

We therefore ask the House to consider our request. We feel more drained, stuck for three long years for permanent residency. Is there any chance the labour government can reduce the period for 491 visa holders? Or at least give us the benefits that permanent residents get?
Isn't it fair to provide us with those benefits because we are and have been working and helping the economy for an extended period? Every 491 holder feels this way!
from 62 citizens (Petition No. EN4536)
Australian Democracy

Our high voter turnout rate has been a proud bedrock of our Australian democracy. According to the Australian Electoral Commission however, the voter turnout rate has slowly declined since the 1990s. Just focusing on the House of Representatives, it has gradually fallen at each federal election, with for example: 95.3% (1990); 94.9% (2001); 93.2% (2010); and 91.9% (2019) of voters casting their vote. Our 2022 election saw only 89.8% of voters casting a vote. (Although COVID was a hurdle in 2022, we had heavy advertising in multiple languages, across traditional media and social media platforms, about voting options with twelve days of early voting, as well as postal and telephone voting options available—all unheard of prior to 2000.) Australia's population has grown significantly since 1990, and this means more voters by percentage and more voters by number, have either disengaged or unengaged from our fundamental Australian democratic system. The voter turnout rate was at least 95% prior to 2000, and it is now closer to 90% as seen at the last three elections. With more than 17 million registered voters, this means some 1.7 million voters within each election decided to not vote in that election. This problem is further aggravated with approximately 5% of actual votes being cast as blank or invalid. The overall long-term decline in voter turnout rates requires urgent attention to reverse this erosion within our Australian democratic system.
We therefore ask the House to comprehensively investigate how to encourage more voters to vote.

Stuttering and Other Fluency Disorders

Stuttering is a common yet widely misunderstood neurological communication disability that affects approximately 70 million people of the world's population. In childhood, stuttering is even more common, affecting 1 in 9 children; a third of which will stutter for their entire lives.

Stuttering, listed as a disability by the Australian Human Rights Commission (2009) and the World Health Organisation's International Classification of Functioning, Disability, and Health (2001), involves so much more than disfluent speech. Coping with stuttering includes wrestling the negative thoughts and emotions, stigma, social penalties, and an unaccepting, uneducated environment that often accompany stuttering throughout the lifespan.

The impact of negative perceptions, attitudes, stereotypes, social consequences, and a lack of knowledge and acceptance of stuttering in society, often leads to adverse effects towards academic achievements, employment opportunities, intimate and social relationships, mental health, and overall quality of life for people who stutter.
As a result, people who stutter often silence themselves and withdraw from their everyday life and relationships, leading to isolation, loneliness…and a world without their voice being heard.

We therefore ask the House to establish a National Stuttering Awareness Week in Australia to help bring stuttering out of the shadows and into the light; provide a platform for people who stutter to share their story; provide the public with true stuttering awareness and help create a more empathic society towards stuttering; and to celebrate all generations of the stuttering community so that they feel proud of the way they speak and no longer feel alone.

from 10,579 citizens (Petition No. EN4572)
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 18 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
First Aid Training
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 27 September 2022 regarding petition (EN3955)—mandatory first aid training for school teachers.
I was saddened to learn of the death of Mr Lucas Latouche Mazzei by choking at Henley Beach Primary School in November 2017. This is truly a tragedy for his family and the entire school community.

I note the petitioner's request that first aid training be made mandatory for all teachers across the country, and I acknowledge that there is a need for teachers at public schools to be adequately trained in first aid. Presently, the exact first aid requirements for teachers varies from state to state, and possibly from school to school.

While the petitioner requests that the Australian Government mandate that all teachers be trained and certified in first aid, decisions regarding the health and safety training requirements for teachers is the constitutional responsibility of state and territory governments or the relevant approved authority (Catholic or Independent) in their respective jurisdiction.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, Mr Clare
COVID-19: Vaccinations
Dear Ms Templeman

I refer to your letter regarding petition EN4008, in relation to recognition of Australia's International COVID-19 Vaccination Certificate (ICVC) in Europe, which was presented in the House of Representatives on 26 September 2022.

Over the first half of 2022, governments across Europe sharply reduced or abolished their requirements for proof of vaccination for everyday access to domestic venues and services. Where such requirements remain, Australia's ICVC is widely accepted. Australia's ICVC is also accepted at European borders that still require proof of vaccination against COVID-19.

Australia's missions in Europe work with local authorities to respond to specific issues that travellers report with proving their vaccination status. Our missions are finding that proof of vaccination is now rarely an issue for Australians in Europe.
Australians seeking up-to-date travel advice on COVID-19 requirements overseas can refer to the department's Smartraveller website to access country-specific information.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Migration
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 27 September 2022 enclosing Petition EN4011, with 156 signatures, concerning pediatric physiotherapists and pathways to permanent residence.

Australia's skilled occupation lists are for the purpose of identifying occupations in Australia where there is a genuine skills need and where migration is an appropriate solution. The Australian and New Zealand Standard Classification of Occupations framework is a skill-based system used to classify occupations and jobs in the Australian labour market and is the responsibility of the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

The occupation Physiotherapist (252511) includes Pediatric Physiotherapist as a specialisation. Physiotherapist (252511) is on the Medium and Long-term Strategic Skills List and is an eligible occupation for temporary and permanent migration. Pediatric physiotherapists can apply for permanent residence under the occupation of Physiotherapist.

At the Jobs and Skills Summit, the Australian Government committed to assessing the effectiveness of the skilled migration occupation lists. This includes the ongoing viability of the role of the Priority Migration Skilled Occupation List, which was introduced by the previous Government to identify occupations considered to be critical for the recovery of the Australian economy, and how it works alongside other skilled migration occupation lists.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4011 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Chronic Pain
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 27 September 2022 concerning Petition EN4024 which seeks an assessment of the 1 March 2022 changes made to Medicare Benefit Schedule (MBS) pain management services.

The changes implemented on 1 March 2022 to MBS pain management services were based on recommendations made by the MBS Review Taskforce in 2019. The MBS Review was a clinician-led, independent process which was undertaken over four years, 2015-2020. The MBS Review involved more than 900 doctors, health professionals and experts to provide advice to Government on how the MBS could be better aligned with contemporary clinical evidence and improve health outcomes for all Australians.

The Pain Management Clinical Committee was established under the Taskforce to review 62 MBS items relating to pain management. This Committee comprised clinical experts across fields of practice including neurosurgery and neuropathic pain, radiology, anaesthetics, specialist pain medicine, and palliative care, as well as consumer representation. The Final Report of the Taskforce on MBS pain management services was published in 2019 and is available on the Department of Health and Aged Care's website at www.health.gov.au/resources/publications/taskforce-final-report-pain-management-mbs-items.

Stakeholder consultation was an integral component of the MBS Review. For the Pain Management Clinical Committee, an 8-week targeted consultation was undertaken from 5 February 2019 to 4 April 2019, with a total of 27 submissions received including from the Australian Medical Association, Australian Society of Anaesthetists, and the Faculty of Pain Medicine—Australia and New Zealand College of Anaesthetists. Following this consultation process, the Pain Management Clinical Committee considered these submissions and amended recommendations prior to finalising their draft recommendations for consideration by the Taskforce in 2019.

Following the finalisation of recommendations by the Taskforce, further consultation was undertaken in 2020 on the consequences of the final Taskforce recommendations via the Pain Management Implementation Liaison Group (ILG). The ILG included representatives from key stakeholder groups, including the Australian Medical Association; Australian Society of Anaesthetists, and the Faculty of Pain Medicine—Australian and New Zealand College of Anaesthetists and feedback was fully considered when making final changes which took effect in March 2022.

Stakeholders did not raise any issues regarding the percutaneous neurotomy services during the ILG or the legislative drafting process. Shortly before implementation of the 1 March 2022 changes, the department was advised of some concerns on the new items for percutaneous neurotomy services. These concerns were quickly addressed in consultation with stakeholders with further amendments taking effect on 11 April 2022 and communicated to the sector in the factsheet available at
www.mbsonline.gov.au/internet/mbsonline/publishing.nsf/Content/77B4A4137E501F71CA2587B1007CAC2F/$File/Additional-information-MBS-pain-management-items.12.04.22.pdf.

As noted in the factsheet a patient can receive percutaneous neurotomy treatment in up to three episodes of care in a 12-month period. An episode of care means one or more percutaneous neurotomy services performed in a single attendance, where clinically relevant. The percutaneous neurotomy items are claimable per joint treated, not per nerve or lesion. More than one joint in the same region can be treated and claimed on the same day (i.e. as part of the same episode), and joints in another region can also be treated in the same episode.

The changes implemented to the percutaneous neurotomy services as recommended by the Taskforce, reflect their concerns that both unnecessary treatments and incorrectly performed treatments pose risks to patients. The clinicians of the independent Taskforce maintained it was not justified to repeat the procedure inside a timeframe of less than 4 months.

The department continues to meet with the Dean, Faculty of Pain Medicine—Australia New Zealand College of Anaesthetists on a regular basis to discuss any other concerns relating to MBS pain management services. In addition, the Australian Government undertakes routine post implementation reviews of MBS changes and intends for a review to be undertaken in early 2024.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Education Workforce
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 27 September 2022 regarding Petition (EN4025)—Request to remove maximum Literacy and Numeracy Test for Initial Teacher Education test attempts.
In response to the issues raised in the petition, I can provide the following advice.

The Australian Government considers that for all teachers, no matter the year level, subjects or students they teach, strong personal literacy and numeracy skills form an essential part of the attributes and skills needed to be effective in the classroom. While personal literacy and numeracy skills are only an element of what makes a good teacher, they are necessary to foster the development of these critical skills in students, providing the building blocks for future learning.

The requirement that all initial teacher education (ITE) students possess personal literacy and numeracy skills broadly equivalent to the top 30 per cent of the Australian adult population has been in place since 2011, when all Education Ministers agreed to introduce the Accreditation of ITE Programs in Australia: Standards and Procedures (Standards and Procedures). Subsequently, in 2015, Education Ministers agreed that, from 1 July 2016, the test would be used as the means for demonstrating a student has achieved this existing literacy and numeracy standard for their profession.

Under the Standards and Procedures, higher education providers have a key role in supporting their students with the test. Higher education providers must ensure entrants to ITE possess levels of personal literacy and numeracy broadly equivalent to the top 30 per cent of the Australian adult population. Providers that select students who do not meet this requirement upon entry into the program must establish satisfactory arrangements to ensure that these students are supported to achieve the required standard before graduation.

The current policy allows enrolled students three attempts to pass the test. In special circumstances, higher education providers may consider that individual students should be granted up to two additional attempts, to make a total maximum of five attempts. From there, ITE students who have exhausted all attempts can apply to have their test attempts re-set after a two-year break from study.

In December 2020, Education Ministers agreed that from 2023, prospective ITE students will have the option to sit the test before they commence their studies. This decision is intended to offer more certainty and fairness to students before they decide to invest time and resources in pursuing a teaching career. This will also give higher education providers the opportunity to provide targeted assistance to students who need additional support to meet the required standard.

As the test requirement is related to the accreditation of ITE programs and/or registration as a teacher, each state or territory is responsible for imposing the requirement relating to the test in that jurisdiction under the relevant state or territory legislation. This includes specifying how the test interacts with progression through an ITE program and/or subsequent registration as a teacher.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, Mr Clare
COVID-19: Vaccination
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 26 September 2022 regarding petition EN4028 requesting that people who refuse to get COVID-19 vaccination should pay for their COVID treatment.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective public health measure to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death. Whilst COVID-19 vaccination is voluntary, as are all vaccinations in Australia, everyone is encouraged to get vaccinated but still maintains the option to choose.

Please note that Medicare is Australia's universal health insurance scheme. It guarantees all Australians (and some overseas visitors) access to a wide range of health and hospital services at low or no cost.

Eligibility for Medicare is defined in the Health Insurance Act 1973 available at www.legislation.gov.au/Series/C2004A00101 and is generally limited to persons who reside in Australia and are either Australian citizens, New Zealand citizens, permanent residents or, in certain circumstances, applicants for permanent residence. Eligibility for Medicare is not dependant on a person's vaccination status.
For access to credible and timely information about COVID-19 vaccines, news and announcements, please visit the Department of Health and Aged care's website at www.health.gov.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
COVID-19
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 27 September 2022 regarding COVID-19 vaccines.

The Australian Government is a strong supporter of immunisation as a safe and effective public-health measure to prevent the spread of many diseases in the community that can cause hospitalisation, serious ongoing health conditions, or even death. The Government's position on COVID-19 vaccination is that it is voluntary, as are all vaccinations in Australia.

As the COVID-19 pandemic is a public-health emergency, states and territories, who have primary responsibility for public-health, are managing the pandemic in their respective jurisdictions based on health advice. In line with this, some states and territories have issued public-health orders which require COVID-19 vaccination for people in high-risk workplaces and sectors, and for some community activities. Further information about these public-health orders can be found on state or territory government websites.

Vaccination providers must obtain consent before administering a COVID-19 vaccine. More information is available at www.health.gov.au/resources/publications/covid-19-vaccination-consent-form-for-covid-19-vaccination. For queries related to human rights please contact the Australian Human Rights Commission at www.humanrights.gov.au.

Prevention of severe illness from COVID-19 remains the primary goal of the ongoing COVID-19 vaccination program. The COVID-19 vaccines currently in use in Australia (AstraZeneca, Pfizer, Moderna and Novavax) provide significant protection against symptomatic disease, hospitalisation and death.

I note your concerns about the safety of COVID-19 vaccines. The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) has comprehensively evaluated each of the provisionally registered COVID-19 vaccines available in Australia to ensure that they meet Australia's high standards of safety, quality and efficacy. A large team of technical and clinical experts at the TGA carefully review the data submitted by the sponsor, which includes clinical trial data (based on individual patient-level data from thousands of participants), to ensure that strict safety and efficacy thresholds are met. Expert advice from the Advisory Committee on Vaccines, an independent clinical expert committee, is also sought prior to a senior medical officer making a regulatory decision under the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989.

A vaccine is only provisionally approved by the TGA if this rigorous process is completed, and the benefits of the vaccine are considered to be much greater than any potential risks. As part of the provisional approval, sponsors are also required to continue to submit longer-term evidence to the TGA.

The TGA has published a range of regulatory documents relating to the provisional approval of each COVID-19 vaccine. These include the Australian Public Assessment Report, the Product Information (Pl) and the Consumer Medicine Information documents, which are available at www.tga.gov.au/covid-19-vaccines.

The TGA also has a well-established and effective system in place to detect and investigate potential new safety issues relating to vaccines. Many of these processes have been enhanced dramatically for COVID-19 vaccines, making this the most intense safety monitoring of therapeutic goods ever conducted in Australia. Gathering adverse event reports is just the first step in determining whether a suspected side effect is related to the vaccine.

The TGA works closely with other regulators around the world and shares information from vaccination programs with reliable adverse events data covering hundreds of millions of people and continually analysing the latest evidence regarding COVID-19 vaccines. With vaccination programs being rolled out across the globe, regulators have access to enormous amounts of real-world data from a variety of sources to add to what we have learned from the initial clinical trials and subsequent follow-up studies.

Please be assured that when the TGA suspects there is a safety issue with a vaccine, they conduct a thorough investigation of the issue. If they determine that the safety concern is significant, they will respond appropriately. This can include updating information about recognised adverse effects in the approved Pl documents, used by vaccine administrators and other healthcare professionals and available on the TGA website. In addition, fortnightly updates are communicated to the public in the COVID-19 vaccine safety report at www.tga.gov.au/periodic/covid-19-vaccine-safety-report. More information can be found at www.tga.gov.au using the search terms 'COVID-19 vaccine safety monitoring and reporting'.
The Government has also invested in a diverse range of treatment options to ensure Australia has sufficient supply of COVID-19 treatments to manage different stages of disease, including:
Paxlovid® (nirmatrelvir + ritonavir) by Pfizer
Lagevrio® (molnupiravir) by Merck Sharp and Dohme
XEVUDY® (sotrovimab) by GlaxoSmithKline
RONAPREVE® (casirivimab + imdevimab) by Roche
Evusheld® (tixagevimab + cilgavimab) by AstraZeneca, and
VEKLURY® (remdesivir) by Gilead Sciences.

The two oral antiviral treatments, molnupiravir and nirmatrelvir + ritonavir were listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) on 1 March 2022 and 1 May 2022, respectively. Eligible patients can access these medicines from their local community pharmacy on a prescription from a medical practitioner or an authorised nurse practitioner in accordance with the PBS requirements. More information can be found at www.health.gov.au under the search 'COVID-19 treatments'.

It is important for Australians to have access to credible and timely information about COVID-19 vaccines. We strongly encourage you to stay up-to-date on all news and announcements, by regularly checking the Department of Health and Aged Care's website at www.health.gov.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler(Petition No. EN4039)
Sexual Consent Education
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 26 September 2022 to the Hon Dr Anne Aly MP, Minister for Early Childhood Education and Minister for Youth, regarding Petition EN4047 to include sexual consent education in the Australian Curriculum. As this matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities, your correspondence has been referred to me for reply.
In response to the issues raised in the petition, I can provide the following advice.

The Australian Government has a zero-tolerance approach towards sexual assault and violence against children and young people. Respectful relationships education has been identified as a key long-term measure to change the attitudes of young people towards issues such as consent and healthy, safe relationships. This includes providing students and young people with the knowledge and skills to better communicate with one another, make responsible shared decisions, understand consent, resolve conflict, and engage in healthy and positive relationships.

The nationally agreed Foundation to Year 10 (F—10) Australian Curriculum sets the expectations for what all students should be taught, regardless of where they live or their background. The curriculum was reviewed by the Australian Curriculum, Assessment and Reporting Authority (ACARA) in 2020-22. Throughout the review, ACARA consulted with subject experts, teachers and the public regarding changes to the Health and Physical Education curriculum, including those related to consent. On 1 April 2022, all Education Ministers endorsed the revised Version 9.0 of the curriculum. Respectful relationships education is specifically embedded in the new Australian Curriculum and is available for jurisdictions to implement in schools from 2023.

The revised Health and Physical Education curriculum strengthens and lifts expectations for the delivery of consent and respectful relationships education. In this subject, students have the opportunity to develop the skills to build and manage respectful relationships, including understanding the concept of consent in age-appropriate ways starting from the Foundation year. The curriculum covers the area of relationships and sexuality, including respectful online relationships and online safety. The curriculum also sets out the General Capabilities of Ethical Understanding and Personal and Social Capability that provide opportunities for students to build their resilience, empathy and ability to resolve conflicts. More information on the Australian Curriculum Version 9.0 is available at v9.australiancurriculum.edu.au.

The Government plays a leadership role in setting and advocating for national priorities in school education. The Australian Government value the work that state and territory governments and non-government education authorities do to manage schools and implement the curriculum. This includes the development of policies for teaching respectful relationships, how the curriculum is implemented, and the selection and use of curriculum resources. In many cases, decisions are made by the individual schools which ensures that school leaders, teachers and communities can tailor education programs and resources to suit students' specific needs and their school's context.

The Australian Government has announced a $77.6 million commitment to support state and territory governments and non-government school systems deliver respectful relationships and consent education in primary and secondary schools. These supports will be evidence based, age appropriate and developed by experts. This commitment will support the implementation of the Australian Curriculum.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Education, Mr Clare
Ukraine
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email enclosing Petition EN4051 concerning Australia's assistance to Ukraine.

Prime Minister Albanese's visit to Kyiv on 3 July this year sent a clear message that democratic nations like Australia will stand side-by-side with the Ukrainian people in their time of need. Our objective is to empower Ukraine to resolve this conflict on its own terms. Australia is proud to have contributed important defence, economic, and humanitarian assistance.

On 27 October, Australia was proud to announce the contribution of 30 additional Bushmaster protected mobility vehicles to Ukraine, bringing the total to 90 Bushmasters. In addition, Australia will join other partners in providing critical training to Ukrainian troops. A contingent of up to 70 ADF personnel will deploy to the United Kingdom in January 2023 as part of the UK's Operation INTERFLEX.

Australia has now provided Ukraine with a total of approximately AUD 655 million in support. This has included AUD 475 million in military assistance to Ukraine, AUD 65 million in humanitarian assistance to help meet the urgent needs of the Ukrainian people, and duty-free access for Ukrainian imports to Australia.

The Australian government acknowledges the significant challenges associated with rebuilding Ukraine. We will continue working with partners to support Ukraine and all formal requests from Ukraine for support will be considered.
I truth this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Migration
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence of 27 September 2022 enclosing Petition PN0539 with 841 signatures, concerning Ms Ji In Kim and Mr Byeong Cheong's request for Ministerial Intervention.

Section 351 of the Migration Act 1958 provides me with the power to substitute a decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal with a more favourable decision, if I think it is in the public interest to do so. This is a non-compellable power and I am not obliged to consider a case or to intervene in a case.

A large number of requests for Ministerial Intervention are received and the Department of Home Affairs has been provided with guidelines on ministerial powers (s351, s417, s501J) regarding which cases should be referred for Ministerial consideration.

Requests for Ministerial Intervention are assessed on a case-by-case basis and processing timeframes vary due to individual circumstances. All information provided with a Ministerial Intervention request is taken into account when considering a case.
Please be assured that the Petition has been noted and will be considered when a decision is made on Ms Kim and Mr Cheong's request.
Thank you for bringing Petition PN0539 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Commonwealth Coat of Arms
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your letter dated 27 September 2022 regarding petition EN3952 which requests that the Australian Government remove the kangaroo from the Commonwealth Coat of Arms.

The Commonwealth Coat of Arms is the formal symbol of the Commonwealth of Australia and signifies Commonwealth authority and ownership. It is predominantly used by Australian Government departments and agencies, statutory and non-statutory authorities, the Parliament and Commonwealth courts and tribunals. The Government has no plans to change the Arms.

The Government takes the welfare of all animals, including native animals, seriously. Australian governments (state, territory and federal) work together to regulate and monitor kangaroo and wallaby sustainability and welfare. We remain committed to ensuring the management of kangaroos is science-based, sustainable and humane.

State and territory governments have primary responsibility for managing kangaroos and other wildlife, including animal welfare. State government jurisdictions regularly undertake scientifically robust population monitoring to ensure kangaroo harvesting is sustainable. Harvest sites and numbers are actively managed where population resilience concerns arise.

State and territory governments carry out commercial harvesting in accordance with the National Code of Practice for the Humane Shooting of Kangaroos and Wallabies for Commercial Purposes (the Code), which was updated in October 2020 and endorsed by key animal welfare organisations. The National Code of Practice for the Humane Shooting of Kangaroos and Wallabies for Non-commercial Purposes is used where animals are taken for non-commercial purposes.

All state-managed harvest of kangaroos and wallabies for international export must have an approved Wildlife Trade Management Plan under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999.

Approved plans ensure commercial harvest is done sustainably and humanely, including in accordance with the Code. I note there has been no adverse long-term impacts on kangaroo populations after more than 40 years of harvesting under commercial management plans, including during periods of severe drought.
Thank you for bringing this petition to the Australian Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister, Mr Gorman
Kashmir
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence regarding petition number EN4023, concerning the rights of the people of Kashmir.

The Australian Government is strongly committed to advancing human rights globally through our bilateral relationships and engagement in multilateral forums, including the UN Human Rights Council. We expect all countries to meet their international human rights obligations including protecting the rights to freedom of religion or belief, freedom of opinion and expression and freedom of assembly and association. Australia opposes the death penalty in all circumstances, for all people.

We regularly discuss human rights matters with our Indian counterparts. The Indian Government understands Australia's principled position to promote, protect and respect human rights, as well as our enduring expectation that all countries uphold the fundamental rights of their citizens.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
International Relations
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence regarding petition EN4037.

I recognise that many Australians' lives and livelihoods continue to be affected by significant global challenges, including the COVID-19 pandemic. We know that we are better off in a world where rules and norms—whether on trade, the maritime domain, military engagement, the environment or human rights—are clear, mutually negotiated and consistently followed.

The UN, especially its network of specialised agencies, sets critical technical and normative standards that matter to Australians, such as those related to standardising measurements, postage services and telecommunications around the world. It is important Australia engages and shapes these standards.

We work closely with the global health community, including the World Health Organization, to improve health and wellbeing for all people worldwide. The International Health Regulations (2005) help ensure timely global responses to health emergencies, and are critical to minimising their health and economic impacts in Australia.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Ukraine
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email enclosing Petition EN4041 that requested the House of Representatives condemn Russia's aggression against Ukraine and recognise the perpetration of war crimes.

The Australian Government has consistently condemned Russia's illegal and immoral invasion of Ukraine, including recently at the Crimea Platform Summit on 23 August 2022, and in Australia's national statement to the United Nations on 23 September 2022. I enclose both statements for your information.

The Australian Government is committed to supporting Ukraine and holding Russia accountable. Australia filed an intervention in Ukraine's case against Russia in the International Court of Justice (ICJ) on 30 September 2022. Australia joined 42 other states to refer the situation in Ukraine to the International Criminal Court (ICC) for investigation on 2 March 2022. The states requested that the Prosecutor investigate any war crimes, crimes against humanity or genocide alleged to have occurred in Ukraine from 21 November 2013. I consider Australia's existing contribution to and support for accountability processes, including the ICJ and ICC, offers the best prospects of ensuring Russia is held accountable.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Encl: National Statement to the UN General Assembly; Australian Statement at Crimea Platform Summit

span.span: Hon Penny Wong Minister for Foreign Affairs Crimea Platform Summit
Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade Tuesday, 23 August 2022

p.span: Thank you Chair
It has been eight long years since Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea. And six long months since Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine.
These are gross violations of international law, and fly in the face of Russia's commitment to Ukraine's territorial integrity under the 1994 Budapest Memorandum.
This is not the first time we have seen such flagrant disregard for international law and human rights from Russia.
We have seen it before in Crimea.
The oppression of hundreds of thousands of Crimean Tatars:
A hostile force imposing its will on peaceful local populations.
Persecuting and exiling a people.
Repressing culture, religion and language.
Destroying cultural relics and holding sham referenda.
In February, Russia sought to replicate this reprehensible strategy throughout Ukraine.
It continues these brutal actions across the Donbas, in Kherson, and elsewhere in southern Ukraine.
Six million Ukrainians are seeking refuge in Europe and countries like Australia.
Another six million are internally displaced.
There is clear evidence of Russian war crimes: torture, mass executions, rape, shelling civilians, and forced deportations, including of children.

Australia deplores Russia's suppression of human rights in Crimea, including arbitrary detentions, arbitrary arrests, torture and forced disappearances, including of the Mejlis of the Crimean Tatar people.

Australia condemns the Russian Government's limitations on freedom of religion and belief, and freedom of expression and association, through the suppression of internal opposition and protest by Russian people against this war.
We call on Russia to immediately:
Withdraw its forces from Ukraine.
Comply with its obligations under international humanitarian law.
Release all Ukrainian prisoners unjustly detained in Crimea.
And allow access by international monitors.

Since 2014, Australia has maintained an autonomous sanctions regime that includes targeted financial sanctions and travel bans against people and entities responsible for, or complicit in, the illegal annexation of Crimea.
Australia has proudly committed 388 million Australian dollars in military assistance and provided 65 million dollars in humanitarian assistance to Ukraine.
We believe in political freedom, human rights, the rule of law, and the rules-based international order.
Prime Minister Albanese's visit to Kyiv on the 3rd of July was the first by an Australian Prime Minister—and it demonstrated the strength of our commitment to those shared values.
We pay tribute to the incredible courage and resilience shown by the Ukrainian people.
Australia stands with them.
Thank you.

span.span: National Statement to the UN General Assembly, New York

p.span: President, it is my honour to speak on behalf of Australia in this venerated General Assembly hall that signifies so much to the world's peoples.
This remains the only place where the whole world has agreed to come together—
Recognising that we can only solve our biggest problems together—
Recognising that progress and development are preconditions for peace—
Recognising that to avoid conflict, we must talk to each other—and we must listen to each other.
It is my honour to speak on behalf of a country that is home to people from more than 300 different ancestries and to the oldest continuous culture on the planet.
Like this hall, Australia is an assembly of the world's peoples.
When Australians look out to the world, we see ourselves reflected in it. Equally, the world can see itself reflected in Australia.
A nation whose people share common ground with so many of the world's peoples. A nation where half our people were born overseas or have a parent born overseas. I am one of those people.
And the Australian Parliament I serve in is ever more reflective of our modern nation, both enriched by their diversity.
This follows the collective decision of the Australian people to turn the page and write a new future for themselves.
Newly elected parliamentarians have origins from across the world, and Indigenous Australians have been elected in record numbers—and serve in the Ministry in record numbers.
The new Australian Government is determined to make real progress on the national journey of healing with Indigenous Australians, the First Peoples of our continent.

As Foreign Minister, I am determined to see First Nations perspectives at the heart of Australian foreign policy, and this week I have been encouraged by discussions with other countries on their own journeys.
I am humbled to be guided in these efforts by First Nations colleagues. Here in New York I am joined by Senator Patrick Dodson.
To many Australians, Senator Dodson is the Father of Reconciliation.
Senator Dodson is a Yawuru man from Broome, in the remote north-west of Australia.
Like many First Nations people, he walks in two worlds: as a Senator and leader in our Parliament; and as an elder, native title holder and ceremony man for his people.

In our Government, Senator Dodson has been tasked with responding to a call from First Nations people for a constitutionally enshrined Voice to the Australian Parliament, as well as treaty and truth-telling.
With daunting challenges facing the world, we have much to learn from First Nations peoples—both at home and in international fora.
Elevating First Nations voices—including right here—has never been more important.
Our nation's history and present show that like anything human, indeed like this institution in which we gather, we are not perfect.
But we aim ever higher. And we look to make our contribution to the world.
Australians see our country as it is, we see the world as it is, and we seek to shape them for the better.
Sharing common ground with so many of the world's peoples means Australians want to see the interests of all the world's peoples upheld, along with our own.

This aim of today's Australia accords with the ambition of an Australian who helped shape the UN's Charter, our former foreign minister and the third President of this General Assembly, Dr Herbert Evatt.
At the 1945 San Francisco Conference where the Charter was written, Evatt challenged the great powers. They wanted a strong Security Council that had control over the General Assembly.

Dr Evatt did not succeed in his fight against the great powers' veto within the Security Council, but he did succeed in ensuring that the General Assembly has the ability to decide its own course, and can address any matter that falls within the UN Charter or the powers and functions of any of its organs.
He understood that small and medium countries cannot simply allow their fates to be decided by the great powers.
He understood that small and medium countries must be able to maintain their sovereign choices, protected by a stable framework of rules.
And he understood that in order to maintain those sovereign choices, the small and medium countries of the world, including Australia, must work together.
These are legacies we renew today.
Dr Evatt also saw economic and social security as the precondition for peace.
He pressed the San Francisco Conference to ensure the UN addresses the broadest range of social, economic and human rights issues, saying:

"Real stability… can only be achieved by building an organisation that will do its utmost to assure the peoples of the world a full opportunity in living in freedom from want as well as in freedom from external aggression."
Some didn't want to extend the UN's ambit to economic and social development. On behalf of Australia, Evatt insisted.
And again, these are legacies Australia renews today.
Despite inheriting the biggest debt in our nation's history, the new Australian Government is determined to play its part in supporting the development of other nations—particularly in our region.
We are alarmed that for the first time, the UN's Human Development Index has declined for two consecutive years, in 2020 and 2021.
The impact of this decline has been most severe on women and girls, with nearly half a billion women and girls now living in extreme poverty.

And the global food security crisis is increasingly grave. More than 800 million people go to bed hungry every night. 345 million people face acute food insecurity. 50 million people across 45 countries are on the brink of famine.
This is a growing scale of human suffering that threatens untold global instability. Australia is increasing our contribution to development assistance by over a billion dollars.
If we are ever to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals, which represent our collective vision for minimum living standards for everyone living on this planet, every country needs to do more.

Over the coming months, we are designing a new development policy, outlining how we will play our part in a world in an era of crisis—and how we will help developing countries without driving them into unsustainable debt.
The world has experienced disasters and conflict in the past. But the intensity and confluence of today's challenges in an interconnected world are without precedent.
COVID-19 has set back development gains.
Russia's invasion of Ukraine has unleashed further suffering and made it harder for populations to recover from the pandemic.
